As JBM mentioned =
in an earlier post, the main purpose of a paper should be to teach the read=
er something new. If it enables future work (and it most likely does), that=
's great, and it's smart to point that future work out in the paper. But to=
 make the main contribution of a paper that it enables future work is most =
likely a fruitless venture that will just end up as an uncited paper if we =
don't follow up on it ourselves. Just look at how many papers go uncited no=
wadays.

> I'm also not clear on why a proof of concept should be relegated=
 to a
> poster.  After all, there's only one proof-of-concept in the known
=
> universe of evolution producing human intelligence and it inspired our
> =
entire research field.
> 
> If I evolved a single HyperNEAT neural network =
with human-level
> intelligence but could not do it again, would you prefer=
 that the result
> remains reported only in a poster?  Would you question t=
he capabilities
> of HyperNEAT because it "only" evolved human-level intell=
igence once?

I wouldn't say that high-level intelligence is a single proof=
 of concept. High-level intelligence has evolved in many species, some exta=
nt and some extinct. It didn't just pop out of nowhere, either -- it was th=
e result of a long chain of evolutionary events in environments that favore=
d animals with high-level intelligence. Thus, it's far more informative to =
understand what mechanisms (e.g., selective pressures) underly the evolutio=
n of intelligence, rather than simply demonstrating a system in which it ev=
olved as a (potentially) rare event. That is why quantification is so impor=
tant. By nature, you must gain some deeper understanding of the phenomenon =
in order to quantify it.

For example, let's say we did evolve an agent wit=
h high-level intelligence using HyperNEAT, qualitatively showed its perform=
ance on some cognitive tasks, and plotted the network as a figure. How woul=
d someone follow up on that? They could take our code and re-run it, but if=
 high-level intelligence is indeed a rare evolutionary event, how would the=
y stand a chance of reproducing our result? If they can't reproduce it, how=
 could they build on it from there? Or, if it takes a huge amount of effort=
 to reproduce the event, is it really worth the effort to build on it?

It'=
s unlikely that we're going to just stumble into something as complex as hi=
gh-level intelligence. It's going to come from a long series of experiments=
 that build on each other as we learn more and more about what constitutes =
intelligence. That's why proofs of concept are insufficient to advance a fi=
eld: They show that something was accomplished (that likely won't be accomp=
lished again anytime soon, e.g., Sims, 1994), but do not teach the reader *=
why* it worked. The *why*, ultimately, is what advances the field.
